answers.answer: Hi,How is your husband? I understand your concern regarding your husband's condition. There is no absolute contraindication for hemodialysis but there are some relative contraindications that his doctors may have considered. There are many possible factors to consider such as your husband's co-morbid conditions as well as his recent heart attack, symptoms and over-all health. It is highly recommended that you talk to his doctors for proper evaluation. Discuss the management plan also to erase any doubts. Take care and best regards.

Thank you so very much for replying to my question.  My husband has had surgery for a fistula in his arm and is hopeful that it will be healed before he has to start dialysis.  He's more comfortable now that he has one person at the congestive heart failure clinic that monitors his symptoms and coordinates the different medications and opinions coming from several different doctors.  This has helped him immensely.  Once again, I very much appreciate your reply.

question: My husband is 67 yrs old, congestive heart failure, insulin dependent diabetes, kidney failure (stage 4 or 5), and his latest test results were BUN 93, Creatinine 14, and GFR 11.   He recently had a minor heart attack and before doing an angiogram(which turned out fine except for two small blocked veins) the hospital put a port in his neck for possible dialysis.  I am at my wits end because, for some reason he's not had any dialysis and I'm not sure why, and I don't believe we're getting enough information from the doctors.  He feels terrible, weak, depressed, and miserable all the time and is unable to do much except sit in his chair.  Can someone explain to me why doctors are so reluctant to start dialysis?  I am wondering if this will ultimately cause him harm.  He does have good urine flow, which must be a factor.  Why not do some dialysis to improve his life?  I would really appreciate someone else's take on this situation.  Thank you in advance, Gladys
title: why delay dialysis?
